I removed/updated these.

items.content_html:
A few direct links to different dictionaries were left and became redirects.

I rephrased the sentences and linked them to the methods using these dictionaries.

There was also a "red link" to an inherited property. I changed the interfaces to use the standard way: not explaining the property there, and adding a sentence indicating the existence of inherited properties, getting rid of the red link.
items.title: Fix redirects caused by removal of dictionaries

items.content_html:
Fixed a typo: The expected value of the CSRF token should be stored on the server, and not on the client in a cookie.

Description

Fixed a typo: The expected value of the CSRF token should be stored on the server, and not on the client in a cookie.

Motivation

Fixed a typo. The original content was wrong and confusing.
items.title: CSRF token should be stored in a server-side database

items.title: Add jsondata l10n translation for ko

items.content_html:
Description

This updates the fetchpriority HTML attribute and priority fetch option to match the final spec.

Motivation

The Priority Hints spec was merged into the HTML and fetch specs, obsoleting the original spec.

Additional details

Here is the HTML spec PR and the Fetch spec PR.

Summarized changes:

  • The iFrame element no longer supports the fetchPriority attribute (was never implemented anywhere).
  • The img, link and script elements point to the appropriate HTML spec pages.
  • The priority option as part of creating a fetch request was updated.
  • A stray reference to the old importance attribute was updated.

One thing that I couldn't quite make out is that the Fetch spec accounts for a Request object but also a RequestInit object that is used when constructing a request. The priority is not readable from Request, it is only settable at construct time. I removed it from the JSON and Request interfaces and added it to the main fetch page where it talks about constructor options but the RequestInit itself doesn't appear to be directly documented.

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #24519
items.title: Update fetchpriority to match final spec

items.content_html:
Description

This PR corrects the descriptions of the sideways-rl and sideways-lr values of the writing-mode property.

Motivation

The existing descriptions are incorrect by the spec, and can be seen from the examples shown on the MDN page for this property.

Additional details

The relevant section in the CSS Writing Modes Level 4:
https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-writing-modes/#block-flow
The examples on the MDN page for writing-mode:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/writing-mode#result
items.title: Correcting the `writing-mode` description

items.title: RTCRtpReceiver.getParameters() and friends - return value not dict

items.content_html:
Description

Clarified that test works whether or not the supplied string is undefined or null.

Motivation

Because I'm not a JS expert, I had to test this functionality manually. Having it documented here would have saved me time. Also, knowing that test works with uninitialized or null strings has value in helping users avoid both NPEs and throwing unnecessary exceptions.

Additional details

None.

Related issues and pull requests

None.
items.title: Clarified use with null or undefined strings

items.content_html:
Description

New attempt at #23911. Make an example that more closely resemble real-world usage of the feature. Add detailed description of what the example demonstrates, how it works, and why. Follow the guidelines for live samples: add sub-sections for HTML, CSS and Result, and add prose explaining the result.

Motivation

The current example is confusing and lacks explanations. As discussed in #23911, at minimum, it's required to add explanations as well as rename the themes from day and night to something not associated with lightness and darkness.

In trying to do that, I realized that it can be modified and improved more subtly than my previous attempt, while having better real-world applications. To quote the guidelines:

Go beyond just demonstrating how each piece of the API or technology works. Consider possible real-world use cases you might try to demonstrate.

As such, the adapted example demonstrates exactly how a real website might use prefers-color-scheme to style itself. Please look at it to see how.

Additional notes

I welcome any feedback and suggestions, especially on the exact colors of Theme A and Theme B. I've checked allow edits by maintainers, so if you are a maintainer you can edit the colors directly. For any other change (e.g. in phrasing), I would prefer if you suggest changes here through discussion. ðŸ™‚
items.title: prefers-color-scheme example - attempt 2

items.content_html:
The examples are incorrect.

Curier is not a web font, so the check call will return true. There is a bug in Chromium where it returns false for nonexistent fonts. Safari and Firefox have the correct behavior.
items.title: Fix examples

items.content_html:
This fuses the different sections for named-color:

  • CSS 1 / CSS 2 / CSS 3 color lists predate Firefox 1 and Chrome 1. No developer has to deal with compatibility problem here.
  • It is easier to browse a complete list, then to have to look in 4 different sections.
items.title: Fuse color sections for named-color
